'''The Killers''' are an American [[Rock music|rock]] band formed in [[Las Vegas]] in 2001 by [[Brandon Flowers]] (lead vocals, keyboards, bass) and [[Dave Keuning]] (lead guitar, backing vocals). After going through a number of short-term bass players and drummers in their early days, both [[Mark Stoermer]] (bass, rhythm guitar, backing vocals) and [[Ronnie Vannucci Jr.]] (drums, percussion) joined the band in 2002.<ref>{{Cite journal|title=The Killers|journal=Billboard: The International Newsweekly of Music, Video and Home Entertainment}}</ref> The band's name is derived from a logo on the bass drum of a fictitious band portrayed in the music video for the [[New Order (band)|New Order]] song "[[Crystal (song)|Crystal]]".<ref name=men200413>{{cite news|last=Bourne|first=Dianne|title=Video: Bernard Sumner joins The Killers in celebration of their 'musical home'|url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/music/bernard-sumner-stage-manchester-arena-1332304|access-date=March 15, 2013|newspaper=[[Manchester Evening News]]|date=February 20, 2013}}</ref>

The Killers have released seven studio albums, each of which reached the top spot on the [[UK Albums Chart]]: ''[[Hot Fuss]]'' (2004), ''[[Sam's Town]]'' (2006), ''[[Day & Age]]'' (2008), ''[[Battle Born (album)|Battle Born]]'' (2012), ''[[Wonderful Wonderful (The Killers album)|Wonderful Wonderful]]'' (2017), ''[[Imploding the Mirage]]'' (2020), and ''[[Pressure Machine]]'' (2021). They have also released a B-sides and rarities [[compilation album|compilation]], ''[[Sawdust (album)|Sawdust]]'' (2007); a live album, ''[[Live from the Royal Albert Hall]]'' (2009); a [[Greatest hits album|greatest-hits album]], ''[[Direct Hits (The Killers album)|Direct Hits]]'' (2013); and a Christmas compilation, ''[[Don't Waste Your Wishes]]'' (2016).

Since 2016 and 2017 respectively, both Stoermer and Keuning have had extended periods of hiatus from the band, though both remain official members. Stoermer mostly retired from touring, citing both exhaustion from the road and lingering effects from a pyrotechnics accident, while Keuning has released a solo album. Despite his hiatus from touring, Stoermer has participated in recording sessions for ''Wonderful Wonderful'' and ''Imploding the Mirage'', and it was announced that Keuning was participating in recording ''[[Pressure Machine]]'', which was released on August 13, 2021. [[Ted Sablay]], who had served as a touring keyboardist and rhythm guitarist for the band since 2006, assumed lead guitar duties for live shows in Keuning's absence, while touring rhythm guitarist and keyboardist Jake Blanton took up the job of bassist and has taken Stoermer's place in live shows. With Sablay moving to lead guitar, the band hired Taylor Milne and Robbie Connolly to play rhythm guitar and keyboards live.

The Killers are considered one of the biggest rock bands of the 21st century,<ref>{{cite news |last=Barlow |first=Eve |date=March 22, 2015|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2015/mar/22/brandon-flowers-killers-interview-album-the-desired-effect |title=Brandon Flowers on The Desired Effect: 'Every song on this album is a single' |work=The Guardian}}</ref> selling more than 28 million records worldwide, including 10.8 million in the US alone.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.colours.cz/artists/the-killers|title=Colours of Ostrava - The Killers|website=Colours.cz|access-date=August 21, 2020}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/business/9485339/killers-catalog-acquired-eldridge-publishing-deal/?utm_source=twitter&utm_medium=social|title=The Killers' Catalog Acquired in Eldridge's First Music Publishing Deal|website=Billboard.com|access-date=November 21, 2020}}</ref> They have performed in over 50 countries and on six [[continent]]s, headlining venues such as [[Madison Square Garden]], [[Wembley Stadium]] and [[Glastonbury Festival]] (2007 and 2019).

==History==
{{More citations needed|section|date=January 2019}}

===2001–2003: Origins and formation===
In 2001, [[Brandon Flowers]] was fired by his first band, a Utah [[synth-pop]] trio known as Blush Response.<ref name=lvw140405>{{cite news |last=Sculley |first=Alan |title=Brandon Flowers Speaks|url=http://www.lasvegasweekly.com/news/archive/2005/apr/14/noise-brandon-flowers-speaks/|access-date=March 15, 2013 |newspaper=[[Las Vegas Weekly]] |date=April 14, 2005}}</ref> After attending an [[Oasis (band)|Oasis]] concert at the [[Hard Rock Hotel and Casino (Las Vegas)|Hard Rock Hotel]] during [[The Tour of Brotherly Love]], Flowers realized his calling was to be in a rock band and began searching for like-minded musicians.<ref name=paste010605>{{cite news|last=Lanham|first=Tom|title=Oasis – Brit-Rock 'n' Role Models|url=https://www.pastemagazine.com/articles/2005/06/oasis.html|access-date=March 16, 2013|newspaper=[[Paste (magazine)|Paste]]|date=June 1, 2005}}</ref> He eventually came across an ad posted in a Las Vegas newspaper by [[Dave Keuning]], a 25-year-old guitarist who had moved to Vegas from [[Iowa]] a year earlier. When the pair met, they bonded over similar musical influences and immediately began writing songs together in Keuning's apartment. They named their band the Killers as that was the name of a fictional band in the music video for the [[New Order (band)|New Order]] song "[[Crystal (song)|Crystal]]".<ref>{{cite web |title=The Killers - The Killers Comment on Mr. Brightside (Watch This) {{!}} Vevo |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rIpYS2d9gzA | archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211029/rIpYS2d9gzA| archive-date=2021-10-29|website=YouTube |access-date=19 July 2020}}{{cbignore}}</ref> In November 2001, they headed to Kill the Messenger Studio in Henderson, Nevada, along with recently recruited drummer Matt Norcross to begin recording a demo; they recorded two tracks: "[[Mr. Brightside]]", which was the first song Flowers and Keuning wrote together, and "Desperate". A month later, they recorded two more, "Under the Gun" and "Replaceable", with Keuning's roommate Dell Neal on bass.<ref name="Almost Famous">{{cite web |last=Patterson |first=Spencer |date=April 15, 2010 |url=http://www.lasvegasweekly.com/news/2010/apr/15/almost-famous/ |title=Almost Famous |work=[[Las Vegas Weekly]] |access-date=November 24, 2019}}</ref>

Keuning and Flowers played their first live show together at an open mic night at the Cafe Espresso Roma in Las Vegas in January 2002;<ref name="Mike DJ Pizzo">{{cite web|author=Mike "DJ" Pizzo |url=https://medium.com/cuepoint/the-night-the-killers-left-las-vegas-e152f5f927cc#.iihk37q5c |title=The Night The Killers Left Las Vegas – Cuepoint – Medium |website=Medium.com |date= October 2015|access-date=December 10, 2016}}</ref> the pair, joined by Neal and Norcross, began playing venues around the city where they would also hand out free copies of their demo.<ref name="Almost Famous"/> The Killers brought a unique style to the small Vegas music scene which was predominately filled with [[Punk rock|punk]], [[nu metal]], and [[rap]] bands; one local reviewer stated, "The Killers, thankfully, don't come across like any other band in town", and described their sound as a mix between the "pop styles of British music and the lo-fi fuzz of modern indie rock".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lvlocalmusicscene.com/band_detail.cfm?BandName=The+Killers&Genre=Alternative |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20021229002808/http://www.lvlocalmusicscene.com/band_detail.cfm?BandName=The+Killers&Genre=Alternative |archive-date=December 29, 2002 |title=The Killers |publisher=LV Local Music Scene}}</ref> However, the Killers, whose early live sound was also described as erratic, had, by the summer of 2002, fired drummer Matt Norcross and replaced him briefly with Brian Havens, who was also eventually fired. Bassist Dell Neal later left the band due to personal reasons.<ref name="Almost Famous"/>

Ronnie Vannucci Jr. joined the Killers shortly before Neal's departure. Vannucci was well known on the Las Vegas music scene, having played in numerous bands since he was young. It was while he was drumming for other bands including Daphne Major and Romance Fantasy in 2002 that he had met the Killers. Ronnie's first show with the band was on August 30, 2002, at a club called The Junkyard.<ref>{{cite news |last=McLean |first=Craig |date=September 14, 2008 |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2008/sep/14/popandrock5 |title=Change we can believe in |work=The Guardian |access-date=November 24, 2019}}</ref> Playing bass for the Killers that night was [[Mark Stoermer]], who was at this point the lead guitarist for local [[progressive rock]] band the Negative Ponies. The band were keen on Stoermer joining them on a permanent basis, but he was initially reluctant to commit. They had first approached him to be the second guitarist when they were considering turning the band into a five-piece, "possibly more like the Strokes, with a keyboard". Stoermer mentioned later on that he could also play bass.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/rock/7454384/killers-mark-stoermer-interview-are-your-stars-out-video-premiere|title=Killers Mark Stoermer Interview |magazine=Billboard |access-date=September 22, 2017}}</ref> The band had continued as a three-piece trying out other bassists until November 2002, when Stoermer eventually accepted the invitation to join. According to [[Ryan Pardey]], who booked many of the band's early shows, "They (the Killers) became a great band when Ronnie and Mark joined. That’s when they finally became a cohesive unit. What Ronnie did — he was the discipline — and Mark was just a solid musician."<ref name="Mike DJ Pizzo"/>

[[File:Killerslogo.jpg|thumb|The band's official logo, first used in 2003]]
While walking through a [[Virgin Megastores|Virgin Megastore]] in Las Vegas in 2002, Flowers noticed the album artwork on the then-new [[Elvis Presley]] compilation album ''[[ELV1S: 30 No. 1 Hits]]''. This gave him the inspiration to use a marquee sign motif as the band's logo. The band hired Vannucci's roommate's girlfriend to design it, and the logo has been used in the band's branding, releases, promotional materials, and merchandise ever since.<ref name=ViewsTitle>Video ''"[https://www.amazon.com/live/broadcast/8c8df2b0-2810-41de-8a54-08b9462c1353-Amazon Music Live Series with The Killers]"'', accessed on 13 September 2020 20:26:40 [[UTC]]</ref>

The four members would get together in Vannucci's garage to work on song ideas. They would also sneak into the band room at the [[University of Nevada, Las Vegas]] (where Vannucci was studying [[classical percussion]]) at night to practice. It was during this period that the band wrote much of their debut album ''[[Hot Fuss]]'' including hit singles "[[Somebody Told Me]]" and "[[Smile Like You Mean It]]".<ref name="being signed">{{cite web |last=Kalil |first=Mike |url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Sep-18-Sun-2005/living/3337781.html/beingsigned |title=In Depth: Killers Rising |publisher=Los Angeles Review Journal |date=September 18, 2005 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110629145124/http://www.reviewjournal.com/lvrj_home/2005/Sep-18-Sun-2005/living/3337781.html/beingsigned |archive-date=June 29, 2011}}</ref> The band continued playing at small venues around their hometown, often playing Sunday nights at a transgender bar named Sasha's (later renamed Tramps).<ref>{{cite news |last=Bychawski |first=Adam |date=July 13, 2011 |url=https://www.nme.com/news/the-killers/57985 |title=Brandon Flowers: "The Killers played transvestite bars" |work=NME}}</ref> It wasn't long before they caught the attention of Braden Merrick, an [[A&R]] rep for [[Warner Bros. Records]] who had come across their demo on a website dedicated to unsigned bands in the Las Vegas area; after attending a live show he offered to help the band find a record deal and eventually became their manager. He took the band to the [[San Francisco]] area, to [[Berkeley, California|Berkeley]], California, to record demos with former [[Green Day]] manager Jeff Saltzman, they then sent the demo tapes out to major record labels in the US. The band was invited to perform at a number of showcases but were ultimately not signed, the band however did catch the eye of Alex Gilbert,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://hackskeptic.com/2011/03/27/the-killers-hot-fuss-2004/ |title=The Killers – Hot Fuss (2004) |publisher=The Hackskeptic's View |date=March 27, 2011 |access-date=September 17, 2012}}</ref> who was an A&R rep from the [[United Kingdom]]. Gilbert took a demo with him back to the UK and showed it to his friend Ben Durling, who worked at the newly formed [[Independent record label|Independent label]] [[Lizard King Records]] in London. Despite not yet meeting the band in person, Lizard King were quick to offer the band a deal based on the strength of the five song demo. The Killers signed with the British label in July 2003.<ref>{{cite news |access-date=April 26, 2008 |url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=KC&p_theme=kc&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=105C0D1604FBCFD8&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM |title=And you can dance to it |publisher=[[Kansas City Star]] |date=September 14, 2004 |author=Sculley, Alan }}</ref>

===2003–2005: ''Hot Fuss''===
On August 19, 2003, the song "[[Mr. Brightside]]" premiered on DJ [[Zane Lowe]]'s [[BBC Radio 1]] show in the UK.{{citation needed|date=November 2019}} The Killers traveled to [[London]] the following month to spend a week playing at influential live music venues across the city. On September 29, 2003, the song "Mr. Brightside" was released in the UK on a limited number of CDs and vinyl records.{{citation needed|date=November 2019}} Critical reviews of both the song and the shows were positive: ''[[NME]]'' noted the band's retro sound, commenting "The Killers steal so smartly, and with such mind-boggling variety".<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/reviews//7193#52vL4EVqD3XpDZxV.99|title=The Killers: Mr Brightside |date=September 12, 2005 |work=NME}}</ref> As a result of the buzz generated in the UK, a number of major labels in the US began showing strong interest in the band and they were invited to play at the [[ASCAP]] CMJ Music Marathon in [[New York City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ascap.com/eventsawards/events/cmj2003/cmj2003.html |title=ASCAP Bands Rock the 2003 CMJ Music Marathon! |publisher=ASCAP |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100206174651/http://www.ascap.com/eventsawards/events/cmj2003/cmj2003.html |archive-date=February 6, 2010}}</ref> They eventually signed with the record label [[Island Def Jam]].<ref name="being signed" />

The band finished recording ''Hot Fuss'' in November 2003 with Jeff Saltzman. They decided to keep many of the previously recorded demos as they felt they had a spontaneity that re-recordings would not have. Shortly afterwards they returned to London having been invited to support [[British Sea Power]] on their UK tour, the band also worked with [[Alan Moulder]] at [[Eden Studios]] and [[Townhouse Studios]] mixing tracks for their upcoming album. They continued playing support slots during the first half of 2004 most notably touring both the US & UK with [[Stellastarr]] and opening for [[Morrissey]] on two occasions. The band filmed their first music video for the Spring 2004 release of "Somebody Told Me" which was to be the band's debut single in the US and second single in the UK. [[Hot Fuss Tour|The band's first headline tour]] started in the UK in May 2004. During the spring and summer of 2004, the group played well-received sets at festivals across Europe and North America which helped add to their growing fanbase.<ref>{{cite news|author=Lynskey, Dorian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2004/jun/26/glastonbury2004.glastonbury1 |title=Glastonbury 2004: Dorian Lynskey on the second day's music |work=The Guardian |location=London |date= June 26, 2004 |access-date=October 30, 2011 }}</ref>
{{Listen
 |filename = The Killers - All These Things That I've Done.ogg |title="All These Things That I've Done"|description=The anthemic "All These Things That I've Done" with its notable refrain "I've got soul, but I'm not a soldier" became one of the Killers' most well-known songs. }}

The Killers released their debut album ''[[Hot Fuss]]'' on June 7, 2004, in the United Kingdom on [[Lizard King Records]] and a week later in the United States on [[Island Records]].<ref name="created">{{cite news |access-date=April 26, 2008 |url=http://seattletimes.nwsource.com/html/entertainment/2002250089_killerstory24.html |title=Let's-start-a-band ad in newspaper created Killers |work=The Seattle Times |date=April 24, 2005 }}</ref> The track listing differed depending on territory, in the UK and Australia "Glamorous Indie Rock and Roll" replaces "Change Your Mind" as track eight. Upon release ''Hot Fuss'' received generally favorable reviews from critics.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.metacritic.com/music/hot-fuss/the-killers |title=Reviews for Hot Fuss by The Killers |publisher=Metacritic |access-date=July 16, 2014}}</ref> Extensive touring and the success of the [[Grammy Award]] nominated singles "Somebody Told Me", "[[All These Things That I've Done]]" and "Mr. Brightside"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rockonthenet.com/archive/2005/grammys.htm |title=47th Annual Grammy Awards - 2005 |publisher=Rock On The Net |date=February 13, 2005 |access-date=July 16, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rockonthenet.com/archive/2006/grammys.htm |title=48th Annual Grammy Awards - 2006 |publisher=Rock On The Net |access-date=July 16, 2014}}</ref> led to the album becoming a huge commercial success. ''Hot Fuss'' reached number one in the UK in January 2005, seven months after its release, and has been certified 7× Platinum in both the UK and Ireland.<ref>{{cite web |access-date=May 2, 2008 |url=http://www.signonsandiego.com/news/features/20070405-9999-lz1w05killers.html |title=Can Killers regain form at UCSD? Stay tuned |work=[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]] |date=April 5, 2007 |author=Nixon, Chris }}</ref> It went on to spend more weeks on the UK Albums chart than any other album that decade, 173 weeks in total. In the US, the album reached its peak position of number seven in April 2005 and has been certified 3× Platinum.{{certification cite ref|region=United States|artist=The Killers|title=Hot Fuss|type=album}}<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.billboard.com/biz/articles/news/1413305/thomas-makes-billboard-history |title=Thomas Makes Billboard History |publisher=Billboard |date=April 27, 2005 |access-date=July 16, 2014}}</ref> It reached the top spot in [[Australia]] in March 2005, where it was certified 3× Platinum. It has also been certified 3× Platinum in [[Canada]], Platinum in [[New Zealand]] and Gold in [[Argentina]], [[Belgium]], [[Germany]] and [[France]]. "Mr. Brightside" would eventually be downloaded 3.7 million times in the United States {{as of|2017|07|lc=y}}.<ref>{{cite magazine| url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/dance/7833003/the-killers-songs-best-remixes-list | location=United States | magazine=Billboard | title=The Killers' Brandon Flowers on Band Shake-Ups and a Crucial Assist From Bono |date=July 13, 2017}}</ref>

The Killers were named the World's Best Selling New Group at the 2005 [[World Music Awards]], the same year they won the [[MTV Video Music Award]] for Best New Artist and were also nominated for three [[Grammy Awards]] with ''Hot Fuss'' being nominated for [[Best Rock Album]]. In the UK, they picked up an [[NME Award]] for Best International Band. The band was recognized by ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' as the "best-selling new rock band of the past year" in June 2005.<ref name="Binelli, Mark 2005">{{cite magazine|author=Binelli, Mark |title=Hitmen: Fueled by Eyeliner and a Love of the Eighties, The Killers Are the Biggest New Band of the Year |magazine=Rolling Stone |issue=June–July |year=2005|pages=97–100}}</ref> Lead singer [[Brandon Flowers]] had also gained media attention, being named both Sexiest and Best Dressed Man at the [[NME Awards]], he had also caused controversy due to some outspoken views on other bands.<ref name="Binelli, Mark 2005"/>

In July 2005, the Killers performed on the London stage of the [[Live 8]] concert, playing "All These Things That I've Done". [[Robbie Williams]] incorporated the song's refrain "I've got soul but I'm not a soldier" into his own performance.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.channel4.com/music/features/L/Live8/live8live.html |title=As it happens: Live 8 live |publisher=Channel 4 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20051224184504/http://www.channel4.com/music/features/L/Live8/live8live.html |archive-date=December 24, 2005 }}</ref> [[Coldplay]] and [[U2]] followed suit and, at their separate concerts played in Las Vegas, with the Killers in the crowd, incorporated the line into their songs "[[God Put a Smile Upon Your Face]]" and "[[Beautiful Day]]", respectively.

The band fired manager Braden Merrick in 2006. Merrick later filed a lawsuit against the band for breach of contract<ref>Butler, Susan. "UpFront: Legal Matters - Old Story, New Twists: Manager Sues Killers". Billboard: The International Newsweekly of Music, Video and Home Entertainment March 11, 2006: 13.</ref> and their new manager and lawyer, Robert Reynolds, for $16 million each.<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.musicradar.com/us/news/guitars/exclusive-killers-lawsuit-attorneys-speak-198332|title = Exclusive: Killers lawsuit attorneys speak|date = February 27, 2009 |publisher =Music Radar |last1 = Bosso |first1=Joe |last2=Leonard |first2=Michael}}</ref> The band counter sued, citing that Merrick's poor management had cost them millions. The case was settled in 2009.<ref>{{cite web |last=Katsilometes |first=John |url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/blogs/kats-report/2009/oct/02/killers-former-manager-reach-settlement-lawsuits/ |title=The Killers, former manager agree to dismiss lawsuits |work=Las Vegas Sun |date=October 2, 2009 |access-date=July 16, 2014}}</ref>

===2006–2007: ''Sam's Town'' and ''Sawdust''===
Shortly after finishing touring for Hot Fuss, the Killers headed back into the studio to start recording their highly anticipated second studio album with producers [[Alan Moulder]] and [[Flood (producer)|Flood]], who were working together for the first time in a decade.<ref>{{cite news |last=Lee |first=Chris |date=July 16, 2006 |url=https://articles.latimes.com/2006/jul/16/entertainment/ca-fasttracks16 |title=Killers try to avoid a 'Fuss' |work=Los Angeles Times}}</ref> ''Sam's Town'' was mostly recorded at [[Studio at the Palms]] in [[Las Vegas]], with finishing touches added to the album at Criterion Studios, London in June 2006. Upon completion of the album, Flowers claimed he felt the band had made "one of the best albums of the past twenty years" and that he wanted the album to capture "everything important that got me to where I am today". In July 2006, the lead single "[[When You Were Young]]" was premiered and it became a hit, gaining another two Grammy Award nominations and mostly positive reviews with many bringing attention to the influence of [[heartland rock]] on the song.

[[File:The Killers in concert.jpg|thumb|left|The Killers performing in October 2006]]
The Killers' second album, ''[[Sam's Town]]'', was released in October 2006 under [[Island Def Jam Music Group]].<ref>{{cite magazine |access-date=May 2, 2008 |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/57738/the-killers-debut-sams-town-in-new-york |title=The Killers Debut 'Sam's Town' In New York |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=July 25, 2006 |author=Cohen, Jonathan }}</ref><ref name=rs111006>{{cite news|last=Goodman|first=Elizabeth|title=On the Charts: Evanescence Debut at Number One, Killers Defy Weak Reviews|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/on-the-charts-evanescence-debut-at-number-one-killers-defy-weak-reviews-20061011|newspaper=Rolling Stone|date=October 11, 2006}}</ref> It received a varied response with some critics praising the album and the evolution of the band and others criticizing and mocking it, most notably it received a scathing review from ''[[Rolling Stone]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.metacritic.com/music/sams-town/the-killers |title=Reviews for Sam's Town by The Killers |publisher=Metacritic |access-date=July 16, 2014}}</ref> The album sold over 706,000 copies worldwide in the first week of release, reaching number two on the US [[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] chart and number one on the UK chart.<ref>{{cite news |title=Killers' second album strikes higher chord |publisher=[[Las Vegas Review-Journal]] |date=October 12, 2006 |author=Bracelin, Jason |url=http://www.neorunner.com/archive/2006/10/13/Killers_Second_Album_Strikes_Higher_Chord.php |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081210182742/http://www.neorunner.com/archive/2006/10/13/Killers_Second_Album_Strikes_Higher_Chord.php |archive-date=December 10, 2008}}</ref> The album has since been certified 5× Platinum in the United Kingdom; 4× Platinum in Ireland; 2× Platinum in Australia, Canada, and New Zealand; Platinum in the United States and Gold in Argentina, Belgium, Germany, and Russia.

The Killers recorded a live session at [[Abbey Road Studios]] for ''[[Live from Abbey Road]]'' on November 29, 2006.<ref>{{cite news |title=EMI cues up feast of fresh albums |publisher=[[Music Week]] |date=October 1, 2005}}</ref> They performed an almost totally unplugged set, which included stripped back versions of the album's title track "Sam's Town", "When You Were Young" and a rendition of the [[Dire Straits]] hit "[[Romeo and Juliet (Dire Straits song)|Romeo and Juliet]]". In December 2006, the band released a Christmas charity song, "[[A Great Big Sled]]", which benefited [[Product Red]]. [[#Annual Christmas singles and Don't Waste Your Wishes|This has since become an annual tradition.]] [[File:Thekillersonstage.jpg|thumb|right|The band during their first arena tour in 2007.]]

In February 2007, the Killers attended the [[BRIT Awards]] in the United Kingdom, where they performed "When You Were Young". The band won two awards — Best International Group & International Album.<ref>{{cite news |access-date=April 26, 2008 |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/arctic-monkeys-scoop-two-brits-but-shun-mainstream-show-436419.html |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20220618/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/media/arctic-monkeys-scoop-two-brits-but-shun-mainstream-show-436419.html |archive-date=June 18, 2022 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live |title=Arctic Monkeys scoop two Brits but shun 'mainstream' show |work=The Independent |location=London |date=February 15, 2007 |author=Akbar, Arifa }}</ref> In the same month, the band's [[Tim Burton]]-directed video for the album's second single, "[[Bones (The Killers song)|Bones]]", won Best Video at the [[NME Awards]].

The band recorded the video for the album's third single "[[Read My Mind (The Killers song)|Read My Mind]]" in [[Tokyo]], [[Japan]] during a break in their [[Sam's Town Tour]]. The single release was accompanied by a remix of the song by the [[Pet Shop Boys]]. Due to high ticket demand, the Killers began headlining arenas including [[Madison Square Garden]] for the first time and also headlined a number of major European festivals during 2007, including [[Glastonbury Festival]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/news/glastonbury/29189|title=Killers headline Glastonbury|date=February 15, 2007|website=NME |access-date=September 22, 2017}}</ref>

{{As of|2017|07}}, the Killers have sold 5.3 million copies of both ''Hot Fuss'' and ''Sam's Town''.<ref>{{cite magazine| url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/dance/7833003/the-killers-songs-best-remixes-list | location=United States | magazine=Billboard | title=The Killers' Brandon Flowers on Band Shake-Ups and a Crucial Assist From Bono
|date=July 13, 2017}}</ref>

The band released a compilation album called ''[[Sawdust (album)|Sawdust]]'', containing B-sides from the band's first two albums, rarities, and unreleased material in November 2007. ''Sawdust'' has been classified Platinum in the UK.<ref name="smoking">{{cite magazine |access-date=April 26, 2008 |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/rockdaily/index.php/2007/09/06/smoking-section-fiona-apple-kanye-west-and-tom-petty/ |title=Smoking Section: Fiona Apple, Kanye West, The Killers, and Tom Petty |magazine=Rolling Stone |date=September 6, 2007 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071212031900/http://www.rollingstone.com/rockdaily/index.php/2007/09/06/smoking-section-fiona-apple-kanye-west-and-tom-petty/ |archive-date=December 12, 2007}}</ref> The album's first single "[[Tranquilize]]", a collaboration with [[Lou Reed]], was released in October 2007.<ref name="smoking" /> The album also featured a cover of "[[Shadowplay (song)|Shadowplay]]" by [[Joy Division]] which was recorded for the soundtrack to the [[Anton Corbijn]] directed biopic ''[[Control (2007 film)|Control]]''.<ref>{{cite news |last=Rayner |first=Ben |access-date=May 2, 2008 |url=https://www.thestar.com/article/275882 |title=Celine takes a chance |work=Toronto Star |date=November 13, 2007 }}</ref>

===2007–2011: ''Day & Age'' and hiatus===
[[File:Brandon Flowers singing for The Killers Day & Age World Tour.jpg|thumb|Brandon Flowers during the Day & Age World Tour]]
The band enlisted [[Stuart Price]] to produce their third studio album, he had previously remixed their songs under his ''Jacques Lu Cont'' moniker, the most notable being the remix of "Mr. Brightside". They first met Price at his London home in 2007 to discuss the possibility of him producing some unreleased tracks for their b-sides album Sawdust, however that same night they ended up in Price's home studio recording a demo of "[[Human (The Killers song)|Human]]" a new song that would become the eventual lead single from ''Day & Age''. The band took six months apart following the completion of their Sam's Town tour, during this period they would send song ideas between each other and Price via [[Logic Pro]]. The band finished recording the album with Price at the band's newly acquired [[Battle Born Studios]] in Las Vegas.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.apple.com/uk/logic-pro/in-action/thekillers/ |title=The Killers: Virtual Sessions |publisher=Apple |access-date=September 16, 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180114105604/https://www.apple.com/uk/logic-pro/in-action/thekillers/ |archive-date=January 14, 2018 |url-status=dead }}</ref>

"Human" was released in October 2008 with Flowers describing the song as "[[Johnny Cash]] meets the Pet Shop Boys". The song went on to become a huge hit worldwide, the lyric "Are we human, or are we dancer?" created much confusion and debate due to its grammar and ambiguity, with some believing the lyric was "dancers" or "denser" rather than "dancer", Flowers explained that the line was inspired by a [[Hunter S. Thompson]] quote where he stated America was raising "a generation of dancers". It has since been voted by one poll as the most confusing song lyric of all time.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gigwise.com/news/93140/human-by-the-killers-voted-most-baffling-lyric|title="Human" by The Killers voted 'most baffling lyric'|author=Trendell, Andrew |date=August 1, 2014 |work=Gigwise}}</ref>

[[File:The Killers at Hipodrom Stožice 2009.jpg|thumb|left|The Killers performing in 2009]]
The Killers' third album, ''[[Day & Age]]'', was released on November 18, 2008. Flowers stated that ''Day & Age'' was "like looking at Sam's Town from Mars", the band have called it their "most playful record" with the album making use of [[saxophones]], [[steel drums]], [[harpsichord]], and tribal chanting. The album also saw the band write some of their most personal and challenging lyrics to date, closing track "Goodnight, Travel Well" was written about the death of Keuning's mother. While "[[A Dustland Fairytale]]" was written as a tribute to frontman Flowers' parents, his mother had recently been diagnosed with [[terminal cancer]]. ''Day & Age'' became the band's third studio album to reach number one in both the UK and Ireland, it reached number six on the [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] album chart.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.billboard.com/search/?keyword=Find+artists+and+musicday+and+age#/album/the-killers/day-age/1185735 |title=Day & Age — The Killers |publisher=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=December 9, 2009}}</ref> It has also been certified 4× Platinum in the UK and Ireland, Platinum in Germany, Australia, New Zealand and Canada and Gold in the US, Mexico, Sweden, Norway, Austria, Switzerland, Greece and the Middle East.

[[File:Set design for The Killers Day & Age World Tour.jpg|thumb|upright=0.75|Set design for the Day & Age World Tour]]
The band embarked on the [[Day & Age World Tour]], during which they performed on every continent and headlined US festivals [[Lollapalooza]] and [[Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival|Coachella]] for the first time. The tour was named one of the top 50 worldwide concert tours of 2009.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pollstarpro.com/SpecialFeatures2009/2009YearEndTop50WorldwideConcertTours.pdf |title=2009 Year End Top 50 Worldwide Concert Tours |publisher=Pollstar |access-date=September 22, 2017 |archive-date=September 9, 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160909074639/http://www.pollstarpro.com/SpecialFeatures2009/2009YearEndTop50WorldwideConcertTours.pdf |url-status=dead }}</ref> On July 5–6, 2009 at the Royal Albert Hall, London the Killers recorded their first live DVD, ''[[Live from the Royal Albert Hall]]''. It was released in November and played at various cinemas across the globe. ''Live from the Royal Albert Hall'' was certified 2× Platinum in the UK, Platinum in the US and Australia and Gold in Ireland and Brazil.

In January 2010, the band announced that they would take a short break after being on the road for the better part of six years.<ref>{{cite news |last=Bychawski |first=Adam |date=January 18, 2010 |url=https://www.nme.com/news/the-killers/49294 |title=The Killers announce they are going on 'hiatus' after current tour |work=NME}}</ref> The break lasted for about a year and a half, during which band members devoted themselves on solo projects, while the band made sporadic other contributions. In late February 2010, Flowers' mother died after a two-year fight with brain cancer. This resulted in the cancellation of dates in Asia. Two Australian dates in Sydney and Perth were also cancelled; however, both the Gold Coast and Melbourne concerts went ahead, with the Day & Age tour finally coming to a close in Melbourne on February 21 when the Killers were the headline act of the [[Good Vibrations Festival]] at [[Flemington Racecourse]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.heraldsun.com.au/entertainment/the-killers-headline-good-vibrations-2010/news-story/a4bcc72239aea7981daf2cc6f01bf491|title=Killers feel Good Vibrations|date=2009-10-23|website=www.heraldsun.com.au|language=en|access-date=2020-02-19}}</ref>

===2011–2013: Return and ''Battle Born''===
The band returned to the stage in 2011 when they headlined the new International [[Lollapalooza]] Festival in [[Santiago]], [[Chile]] on April 2, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.puntoticket.com/Evento.aspx?EventoID=LOL001 |title=The Killers, Jane's Addiction y Kanye West encabezan el primer show internacional de Lollapalooza |publisher=Puntoticket.com |language=es |access-date=September 13, 2015}}</ref> They also performed at the season closing Top of the Mountain concert in [[Ischgl]], [[Austria]] on April 30, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ischgl.com/de/eventarchiv-tirol-ischgl/the-killers_topevent81109 |title=Ischgl – Fulminanter Saisonabschluss mit "The Killers" |publisher=Ischgl.com |language=de |access-date=September 13, 2015}}</ref> They headlined [[Hard Rock Calling]] for the second time in [[Hyde Park, London]] on June 24, 2011.<ref>{{cite web |last=Bychawski |first=Adam |url=https://www.nme.com/news/the-killers/56169 |title=The Killers to headline London's Hard Rock Calling – ticket details |work=NME |date=April 18, 2011 |access-date=August 17, 2011}}</ref> The Killers were also the inaugural headliner of the new Orlando Calling Festival in [[Orlando, Florida]] on November 12, 2011.<ref>{{cite web |last=Graff |first=Gary |date=July 21, 2011 |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/photos/live/469154/bob-seger-kid-rock-the-killers-top-inaugural-orlando-calling-fest-lineup |title=Bob Seger, Kid Rock, The Killers Top Inaugural Orlando Calling Fest Lineup |publisher=Billboard}}</ref>

[[File:Killers EMU 17 (8399973973).jpg|thumb|right|Brandon Flowers in 2012]]
The band headed back into the studio to record their fourth studio album in 2011, during the recording they worked with five producers [[Steve Lillywhite]], Damian Taylor, [[Brendan O'Brien (music producer)|Brendan O'Brien]], [[Stuart Price]] and [[Daniel Lanois]].<ref name="nme.com">{{cite web |last=Bychawski |first=Adam |url=https://www.nme.com/news/the-killers/64012 |title=The Killers name their new album |work=NME |date=May 28, 2012 |access-date=September 17, 2012}}</ref> In June 2012, a short trailer was released on the Killers official [[VEVO]] page, revealing the album's name ''[[Battle Born (album)|Battle Born]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T9M61MGFRoY| archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211029/T9M61MGFRoY| archive-date=2021-10-29|title=The Killers - Battle Born: Official Album Trailer|work=YouTube}}{{cbignore}}</ref> named after the [[flag of Nevada]]. This was followed by the release of lead single "[[Runaways (The Killers song)|Runaways]]" in July. That same month, they headlined Saturday night at the inaugural [[Firefly Music Festival]] in [[Dover, Delaware]].

The Killers' fourth studio album ''[[Battle Born (album)|Battle Born]]'' was released on September 18, 2012. The album became the Killers' fourth consecutive No. 1 album in the UK and Ireland and has been certified Platinum in the UK and Gold in Ireland, Mexico and Australia. The band's [[Battle Born World Tour]] proved their most widespread yet with the band visiting new territories including Russia and China. The tour was named the 43rd highest grossing worldwide during 2013.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.pollstarpro.com/files/charts2013/2013YearEndTop100WorldwideTours.pdf |title=2013 Year End Top 100 Worldwide Tours |publisher=Pollstar |access-date=September 22, 2017 |archive-date=September 24, 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924075545/http://www.pollstarpro.com/files/charts2013/2013YearEndTop100WorldwideTours.pdf |url-status=dead }}</ref> On June 22, 2013, the band played their biggest show to date at the 90,000 capacity [[Wembley Stadium]]; the band performed a song specifically written for the occasion. Reviews of the show were extremely positive.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2013/jun/23/killers-wembley-stadium-review | location=London | work=The Guardian | first=Mark | last=Beaumont | title=The Killers – review | date=June 23, 2013}}</ref> The band once again headlined festivals across Europe, Australia, South America & North America. In October 2013 the Killers headlined the inaugural Life Is Beautiful Festival in hometown Las Vegas, concluding their Battle Born World Tour.

===2013–2016: ''Direct Hits''===
On September 11, 2013, the band [[Twitter|tweeted]] a picture, which contained six lines of [[Morse code]]. The code was translated to "The Killers Shot at the Night". On September 16, 2013, exactly ten years to the day of their first show in London, the Killers released "[[Shot at the Night]]" which was produced by [[Anthony Gonzalez (musician)|Anthony Gonzalez]]. It was also revealed that they would be releasing their first [[greatest hits]] compilation, ''[[Direct Hits (The Killers album)|Direct Hits]]'' released on November 11, 2013.<ref>{{cite web |last=McGovern |first=Kyle |date=September 16, 2013 |url=https://www.spin.com/2013/09/killers-m83-shot-at-the-night-stream-direct-hits-greatest/|title=The Killers Team With M83 for One Glistening 'Shot at the Night'|work=Spin}}</ref> The album featured songs from all four studio albums, the new single "Shot at the Night" and another new song "[[Just Another Girl (The Killers song)|Just Another Girl]]". The release of ''Direct Hits'' was followed by a short promotional tour, the band also played a number of festivals in 2014.

The band headlined the opening night of the new [[T-Mobile Arena]] on the [[Las Vegas strip]] on April 6, 2016, the band were joined during their set by a number of guests including "Mr. Las Vegas" [[Wayne Newton]] and the [[Blue Man Group]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Katsilometes |first=John |url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/the-strip/t-mobile-arena/what-others-are-saying-about-t-mobile-arena |title=What others are saying about T-Mobile Arena – Las Vegas Review-Journal |publisher=Reviewjournal.com |date=April 1, 2016 |access-date=May 3, 2017}}</ref> On May 24, 2016, the band announced that Mark Stoermer was taking a break from touring "to pursue other educational goals and releasing a solo album". The statement emphasized that Stoermer was still involved in working on the band's fifth album and will still occasionally perform live with them in the future.<ref>{{cite web|last=Buchanan |first=Brett |url=http://www.alternativenation.net/the-killers-bassist-announces-indefinite-hiatus-from-touring-with-band/ |title=The Killers Bassist Announces Indefinite Hiatus From Touring With Band |website=AlternativeNation.net |date=May 24, 2016 |access-date=December 10, 2016}}</ref> In Stoermer's absence touring keyboardist/guitarist Jake Blanton moved to bass guitar. On September 30 and October 1, 2016, the band (including Stoermer) celebrated the tenth anniversary of their second album, ''Sam's Town'', by playing two nights at the [[Sam's Town Hotel and Gambling Hall, Las Vegas|Sam's Town Hotel and Gambling Hall]], which the album was named after. For these shows, they played the album in full from start to finish.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bracelinlas |first=Jason |url=http://www.reviewjournal.com/neon/sounds/the-killers-celebrate-their-town-rousing-intimate-show |title=The Killers celebrate their 'Town' with rousing, intimate show | Las Vegas Review-Journal |website=Reviewjournal.com |date=October 1, 2016 |access-date=December 10, 2016}}</ref> The band contributed a track titled "Mixed Signals" to [[Robbie Williams]]' eleventh studio album, ''[[The Heavy Entertainment Show]]'', released in November 2016.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/robbie-williams-287-1555020|title=Listen To Robbie Williams' album sampler featuring his new song written by The Killers|date=October 17, 2016|website=NME |access-date=September 22, 2017}}</ref>

=== 2017–2018: ''Wonderful Wonderful'' ===

The Killers released their fifth studio album, [[Wonderful Wonderful (The Killers album)|''Wonderful Wonderful'']], on September 22, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|title=Wonderful Wonderful - The Killers|url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/wonderful-wonderful-mw0003091661|first=Stephen Thomas|last=Erlewine|author-link=Stephen Thomas Erlewine|work=[[AllMusic]]|access-date=November 22, 2019}}</ref> The album was produced by [[Jacknife Lee]] and lead single "[[The Man (The Killers song)|The Man]]" was released on June 14, 2017.<ref>{{cite AV media notes |title=Wonderful Wonderful |type=deluxe edition liner notes |others=The Killers |publisher=[[Island Records]] |year=2017 |id=B0027259-02}}</ref>
<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/the-killers-new-single-the-man-2088704|title=Listen to The Killers' new single 'The Man'|work=NME|date=June 14, 2017|access-date=November 22, 2019}}</ref> Before the album's release the band headed to Europe for a number of summer festival dates, including a secret set at Glastonbury Festival, where Stoermer joined them to perform on the John Peel Stage, the same stage they had performed on during their first appearance at the festival 13 years earlier. The run of shows concluded with a sold-out headline performance at the British Summer Time festival in London's Hyde Park.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/music/2017/jul/09/the-killers-review-hyde-park-london-brandon-flowers|title=The Killers review – snake-hipped showman delivers synth-rock glory|last=Gittins|first=Ian|date=July 9, 2017|work=The Guardian|access-date=July 9, 2017|language=en-GB|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>

On August 6, 2017, it was announced that Dave Keuning was going on an indefinite hiatus from the band, citing exhaustion from a grueling tour schedule and a desire to spend more time with his son.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Foster |first1=Alistair |title=Killers guitarist: Walking away from band was hardest decision |url=https://www.standard.co.uk/showbiz/celebrity-news/killers-guitarist-dave-keuning-walking-away-from-band-was-hardest-decision-a4013571.html |access-date=5 January 2021 |work=www.standard.co.uk |date=10 December 2018 |language=en}}</ref>

The Killers released a statement on August 28, 2017, confirming that neither Stoermer nor Keuning would participate in the band's upcoming Wonderful Wonderful World Tour, while reiterating that both are still members of the band. Jake Blanton would continue to fill in for Stoermer while touring guitarist/keyboardist [[Ted Sablay]] would fill in for Keuning.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/thekillers/status/902279938304131072|title=pic.twitter.com/XPf6GbFUK0|first=The|last=Killers|date=August 28, 2017|publisher=[[Twitter]]|access-date=September 22, 2017}}</ref> The band added another two touring musicians: keyboardist/rhythm guitarist Robbie Connolly and rhythm/lead guitarist Taylor Milne, a member of [[Big Talk]], Vannucci's project.<ref>{{cite web|first=Ben|last=Kaye|url=https://consequenceofsound.net/2017/09/the-killers-deliver-stylish-performance-of-the-man-on-colbert-watch/|title=The Killers deliver stylish performance of "The Man" on Colbert: Watch|website=[[Consequence of Sound]]|date=September 22, 2017|access-date=November 22, 2019}}</ref>

The band headlined the [[2017 AFL Grand Final]] in Melbourne, Australia on September 30, 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.foxsports.com.au/afl/afl-locks-in-grand-final-entertainment-nrl-close-to-confirming-its-entertainment/news-story/2c845b963f7fe866ea86506544158faa |title=AFL locks in Grand Final entertainment, NRL close to confirming its entertainment |website=FoxSports.com |date=June 8, 2017 |access-date=June 8, 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theage.com.au/afl/afl-news/richmonds-riewoldt-impresses-with-killers-performance-20170930-gys0ds.html |title=Richmond's Riewoldt impresses with Killers performance |website=[[The Age]] |date=October 1, 2017 |access-date=October 1, 2017}}</ref> Following the conclusion of the game, the band also headlined a free concert at the [[Melbourne Cricket Ground|Melbourne Cricket Ground (MCG)]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.news.com.au/sport/afl/so-awkward-richos-killer-interview-with-rock-band/news-story/a958e6e9bb498f4c8d4b650fa4592dc4 |title=The Killers universally praised for awesome AFL Grand Final concert | website=news.com.au |date=September 30, 2017 |access-date=October 1, 2017}}</ref> and earned praise for their performance. They also welcomed onstage [[Jack Riewoldt]], a fan and a vice-captain of the [[Richmond Football Club|Richmond]] side that had been victorious against [[Adelaide Football Club|Adelaide]] in the Grand Final, to perform "Mr. Brightside" with them.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://au.sports.yahoo.com/afl/a/37295537/jack-riewoldts-epic-grand-final-celebrations-with-the-killers/ |title=Riewoldt's epic Grand Final celebration with The Killers | website=Yahoo! Sports |date=September 30, 2017 |access-date=October 1, 2017}}</ref>

[[File:The Killers Sydney 2018.jpg|thumb|left|Confetti falls during the Killers' Sydney concert in April 2018.]]

''Wonderful Wonderful'' became the band's first album to reach the number one spot on the [[Billboard 200|US ''Billboard'' 200]];<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/chart-beat/7981900/the-killers-first-no-1-album-billboard-200-chart-wonderful-wonderful|title=The Killers Earn First No. 1 Album on Billboard 200 Chart With 'Wonderful Wonderful'|magazine=Billboard |access-date=October 7, 2017}}</ref> it also claimed the top spot on the [[UK Album Chart]], making the Killers the first international act to have their first five studio albums reach number one in the UK.<ref name="officialcharts.com">{{cite web|url=http://www.officialcharts.com/chart-news/the-killers-set-new-official-chart-record-with-fifth-number-1-album-wonderful-wonderful__20603/|title=The Killers' Wonderful Wonderful becomes their fifth UK Number 1 album|website=Official Charts |access-date=October 7, 2017}}</ref>

In May 2018, Flowers told the ''[[Irish Independent]]'' that he wanted to make another album with the band.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.ie/entertainment/music/im-a-student-a-sponge-a-thief-killers-frontman-brandon-flowers-talks-fatherhood-irish-connections-and-bonos-advice-36918694.html|title='I'm a student, a sponge, a thief' - Killers frontman Brandon Flowers talks fatherhood, Irish connections and Bono's advice|last=Meagher|first=John|date=May 20, 2018|work=[[Irish Independent]]|access-date=May 27, 2018}}</ref> In October 2018, guitarist Dave Keuning told ''NME'' that the band was in the early stages of the next album, though he wasn't sure how big a role he would have in its creation process.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/killers-dave-keuning-solo-album-prismism-future-band-listen-interview-2389268|title="I regret not doing it a lot sooner": The Killers' Dave Keuning tells us about his debut solo album 'Prismism'|date=October 12, 2018|work=NME|access-date=October 15, 2018|language=en-US}}</ref>

On January 14, 2019, the band released the standalone track, "Land of the Free", the official music video for which was directed by [[Spike Lee]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.musicnewsnet.com/2019/01/the-killers-release-new-song-land-of-the-free-music-video-by-spike-lee.html|title=The Killers Release New Song "Land Of The Free" & Music Video By Spike Lee|website=Music News Net}}</ref> It was announced that the Killers would be performing at [[Woodstock 50]], though Woodstock 50 was canceled after a series of permit and production issues, venue relocations, and artist cancellations.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/woodstock-50-details-full-lineup-with-jay-z-dead-company-killers-809290/|title=Woodstock 50 Details Full Lineup With Jay-Z, Dead & Company, Killers |website=Rollingstone|date=March 19, 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://variety.com/2019/music/news/woodstock-50-off-dead-1203286874/|title=Woodstock 50 Officially Off|last=Shirley|first=Halperin|date=July 31, 2019|work=Variety|access-date=December 17, 2019|url-status=live|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190731185730/https://variety.com/2019/music/news/woodstock-50-off-dead-1203286874/|archive-date=July 31, 2019}}</ref>

=== 2019–2020: ''Imploding the Mirage'' ===
On November 15, 2019, the Killers announced their 6th studio album titled ''[[Imploding the Mirage]]'' for a Spring 2020 release.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/the-killers-announce-new-album-imploding-the-mirage/|title=The Killers Announce New Album Imploding the Mirage |website=Pitchfork}}</ref> On that day, the band also announced a UK and Ireland stadium tour to take place in May and June 2020.<ref>{{cite magazine|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-news/the-killers-new-album-imploding-the-mirage-913133/|title=The Killers Announce New Album 'Imploding the Mirage' |magazine=Rolling Stone|date=November 15, 2019 }}</ref> On March 12, 2020, the album's lead single "[[Caution (The Killers song)|Caution]]" was released featuring a solo by [[Lindsey Buckingham]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/listen-to-the-killers-teasing-new-track-caution-out-this-thursday-2623140|title=Listen to The Killers teasing new track Caution, out this Thursday |website=NME}}</ref> Lindsey Buckingham said of the band, "There’s such a strong center to what they're doing. Their material is so well crafted that it cuts across a lot of generational lines."<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/music/story/2020-08-19/killers-brandon-flowers-imploding-the-mirage |title=After leaving Las Vegas, Brandon Flowers and the Killers broaden their horizons |work=Los Angeles Times |last=Wood |first=Mikael |date=August 19, 2020 |access-date=July 6, 2021 }}</ref> It was also confirmed by Flowers that Keuning did not participate in recording the album and that he will still not be touring with the band.<ref>{{cite tweet |url=https://twitter.com/NewsTheKillers/status/1216839447557242881 |title=Brandon Flowers discusses ‘Imploding The Mirage’, confirms Dave Keuning has not been involved in the recording of the album, and states that Shawn Everett is producing the album |user=NewstheKillers |number=1216839447557242881 |date=January 13, 2020 |access-date=July 6, 2021}}</ref> On April 25, 2020, "Caution" reached number one on ''Billboard''{{'}}s [[Alternative Songs]] chart, setting a record of 13 years and 6 months since the band's last number-one song on the chart.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/business/chart-beat/9362130/the-killers-break-record-longest-time-between-alternative-songs-no-1s|title=The Killers Break Record for Longest Time Between Alternative Songs No. 1s|date=April 20, 2020|website=Billboard.com|access-date=August 21, 2020}}</ref>

In an interview with ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' published on May 5, 2020, Flowers and Vannucci stated that while Keuning is on hiatus from the band and that they had difficulties in working on the new album without him, he is still welcome to return to the Killers. === 2020–2021: ''Pressure Machine'' and Keuning's return ===
On the weekend of ''Imploding the Mirage'''s release, Flowers revealed that the band was currently in the studio working on their seventh studio album: "You know when someone makes a record and they say that they have fifty songs and they’re going to release another record? Well, we really are! We’re going to release another one in about ten months. We’ve already gone back into the studio with [producers Jonathan] [[Jonathan Rado|Rado]] and [[Shawn Everett|Shawn [Everett]]]. I’m excited. It might be better than [''Imploding the Mirage'']."<ref name="NMEInterview2020">{{cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/big-reads/the-killers-cover-interview-2020-imploding-the-mirage-2734024|title=The Killers: "Music made it possible for me to dream" |work=[[NME (magazine)|NME]]|last=Trendell|first=Andrew|date=August 21, 2020|access-date=August 23, 2020}}</ref> The band revealed in 22 December a provisional "A-List" of "apparent song titles on social media, sparking speculation that another new album could be on the way".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/the-killers-a-list-tracklist-new-album-rumours-2844555 |title=The Killers spark new album speculation by sharing mysterious tracklist |work=NME |last=Trendell |first=Andrew |date=December 22, 2020 |access-date=July 6, 2021 }}</ref> In January 2021, Dave Keuning reunited with the band in the studio and are preparing to release their 7th studio album. Keuning also said that he and Mark Stoermer are open to playing live with the band.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/the-killers-reunite-with-guitarist-dave-keuning-in-studio-for-bands-new-album-2864469 |title=The Killers reunite with guitarist Dave Keuning in studio for band's new album |work=NME |last=Krol |first=Charlotte |date=January 25, 2021 |access-date=July 6, 2021 }}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/music-features/killers-guitarist-dave-keuning-interview-1157962/ |title=Killers Guitarist Dave Keuning Explains Why He Left The Group, How He Returned |magazine=Rolling Stone |last=Greene |first=Andy |date=April 22, 2021 |access-date=June 6, 2021 }}</ref> During a podcast interview in June, Vannucci revealed that the album would be released in August.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Moore |first1=Sam |title=The Killers' new album is coming in August and will be "very different" |url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/the-killers-new-album-is-coming-in-august-and-will-be-very-different-2971142 |website=NME |access-date=21 June 2021 |date=16 June 2021}}</ref>

Earlier in 2021, the band moved performance rights management from [[ASCAP]] to [[Irving Azoff]]-owned performance rights organization Global Music Rights.

On June 10, 2021 [[Bruce Springsteen]] announced an upcoming collaboration with the Killers.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2021/music/news/bruce-springsteen-talks-broadway-killers-mellencamp-tour-1234993677/|title=Bruce Springsteen Talks 'Broadway' Return, New Music with Killers and John Mellencamp, and 2022 tour?|publisher=Variety |access-date=2021-06-10}}</ref> Later that day the Killers' social media announced the remake of "[[A Dustland Fairytale]]" retitled "Dustland" after a series of teases by the band throughout the day.<ref>{{cite tweet|url=https://twitter.com/thekillers/status/1403116617924415488| title=Looks like the cat's out of the bag. |user=thekillers |number=1403116617924415488 |date=June 10, 2021 |access-date=2021-06-10}}</ref>

As it was announced on July 19, 2021, the band's seventh album, entitled ''[[Pressure Machine]]'', was released on August 13, 2021. Mark Stoermer remained absent due to difficulties presented by the COVID-19 Pandemic during recording and did not make it to the studio.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/the-killers-announce-seventh-album-pressure-machine-2997109|title=The Killers announce seventh album 'Pressure Machine'|website=Nme.com|date=July 19, 2021|access-date=August 14, 2021}}</ref> ''The Forty-Five''<nowiki/>'s Rhian Daly called it a "quiet, poetic character study of small-town life."<ref>{{Cite web|last=Daly|first=Rhian|date=2021-08-14|title=The Killers – 'Pressure Machine' review: a quiet, poetic character study of small-town life|url=https://thefortyfive.com/opinion/reviews/the-killers-pressure-machine-album-review/|access-date=2021-08-17|website=The Forty-Five|language=en-GB}}</ref> ''[[Pressure Machine]]'' debuted at No. 1. on the  Official U.K. Albums Chart, snagging the band's seventh U.K. No. 1.<ref>{{Cite magazine|last=Brandle|first=Lars|title=The Killers Snag Seventh U.K. No. 1 With 'Pressure Machine'|url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/9617496/the-killers-seventh-uk-no-1-pressure-machine/|date=August 22, 2021|access-date=August 23, 2021|magazine=Billboard}}</ref>

=== 2021–present: Upcoming eighth album===
In June 2021, Keuning confirmed that the band had begun working on their eighth album, for which Flowers alluded to an early 2023 release in July 2022.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/the-killers-have-made-a-good-start-on-their-eighth-album-says-dave-keuning-2980731|title=The Killers have made "a good start" on their eighth album, says Dave Keuning|website=Nme.com|date=June 29, 2021|access-date=August 14, 2021}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |last1=Lavin |first1=Will |title=The Killers are planning to release a new album early next year |url=https://www.nme.com/news/music/the-killers-are-planning-to-release-a-new-album-early-next-year-3265308 |website=NME |access-date=11 July 2022 |date=8 July 2022}}</ref>

In March 2022, the band released a deluxe edition of ''Pressure Machine''. The next month they kicked off their Imploding the Mirage tour with three nights at the Chelsea Ballroom in the [[Cosmopolitan of Las Vegas]]. Bassist Mark Stoermer was still absent, his part covered on tour by Jake Blanton, but Stoermer was reportedly interested in recording the band's next album, their eighth.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://consequence.net/2022/04/the-killers-las-vegas-review/amp/|title=The Killers Kick Off "Imploding the Mirage Tour" with Raucous Hometown Gig in Vegas: Recap + Photos|website=consequence.net|access-date=April 15, 2022}}</ref>

On July 8, 2022, the band unveiled their upcoming single "Boy" during their performance at [[Mad Cool|Mad Cool Festival]] in Madrid. The song was written during the ''Pressure Machine'' recording sessions but didn't fit the album's aesthetic. During an interview with ''NME'' Flowers confirmed they have been working on their eighth album, stating there would be more single releases in 2022 leading to the album's release early 2023.<ref>{{Cite web |last=Beaumont |first=Mark |date=2022-07-11 |title=How the live premiere of The Killers' new song 'Boy' could point to a bold future |url=https://www.nme.com/features/opinion/the-killers-boy-mad-cool-festival-premiere-3265758 |access-date=2022-07-13 |website=NME |language=en-GB}}</ref>

===Annual Christmas singles and ''Don't Waste Your Wishes''===
Beginning in 2006, the Killers released annual Christmas themed singles and videos in aid of the charity [[Product Red]], supporting [[The Global Fund to Fight AIDS, Tuberculosis and Malaria]]. The band released ten Christmas themed songs and music videos as singles: "[[A Great Big Sled]]" (2006), "[[Don't Shoot Me Santa]]" (2007), "[[Joseph, Better You than Me]]" (2008), "[[Happy Birthday Guadalupe!]]" (2009), "[[Boots (The Killers song)|Boots]]" (2010), "[[The Cowboys' Christmas Ball]]" (2011), "[[I Feel It in My Bones]]" (2012), "[[Christmas In LA]]" (2013), "[[Joel the Lump of Coal]]" (2014), and "[[Dirt Sledding]]" (2015). On November 30, 2011, they released the ''[[(RED) Christmas EP]]'' on iTunes which features all six songs that had been released up to that point. Over the years they have enlisted the help of other musicians and celebrities including [[Elton John]], [[Neil Tennant]] (Pet Shop Boys), [[Toni Halliday]] (Curve), [[Wild Light]], [[Mariachi El Bronx]], [[Dawes (band)|Dawes]], [[Owen Wilson]], [[Jimmy Kimmel]] & [[Richard Dreyfuss]]. In 2016 they announced that they would be releasing no more Christmas singles but that they hoped another band would carry on the tradition, to wrap things up they released a compilation album ''[[Don't Waste Your Wishes]]'' featuring all ten previous singles plus a cover of the holiday classic "[[I'll Be Home For Christmas]]" which featured vocals from Brandon Flowers' former [[elementary school]] teacher and [[Korean War]] veteran Ned Humphrey Hansen. All proceeds from the songs and the compilation album have been and will be donated to Product Red campaign and the fight against AIDS in Africa and {{as of|2016|lc=y}} they have raised over $1 million for the charity.<ref>{{cite press release |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/the-killers-celebrate-a-decade-of-red-holiday-singles-with-release-of-new-christmas-album-dont-waste-your-wishes-on-itunes-300366648.html |location=New York |title=The Killers Celebrate A Decade Of (RED) Holiday Singles With Release Of New Christmas Album, 'Don't Waste Your Wishes,' On iTunes |website=PR Newswire |date=November 21, 2016 |access-date=December 10, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://red.org/dirt-sledding-the-killers-10th-annual-christmas-single-for-red-featuring-ryan-pardey-richard-dreyfuss/ |title=Dirt Sledding: The Killers 10th Annual Christmas Single for (RED) Featuring Ryan Pardey Richard Dreyfuss | (RED) |access-date=May 3, 2017 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151208051004/https://red.org/dirt-sledding-the-killers-10th-annual-christmas-single-for-red-featuring-ryan-pardey-richard-dreyfuss/ |archive-date=December 8, 2015}}</ref><ref name="rollingstone1">{{cite web|last=Legaspi |first=Althea |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/the-killers-to-release-new-christmas-charity-album-w451148 |title=The Killers to Release New Christmas Charity Album |publisher=Rolling Stone |date=November 18, 2016 |access-date=December 10, 2016}}</ref>
